qc.notes: All 10 required poses were provided and are of good quality. Some minor specular glare is present on the T-zone but does not significantly impede analysis; it was used as a corroborating signal for skin type assessment.

skin_type.label: combination
skin_type.rationale: Your T-zone (forehead, nose, and chin) shows a noticeable glossiness across multiple photos, which suggests higher oil production in this area. In contrast, your cheeks appear less shiny and more balanced. This difference in sebum levels between the central face and the outer areas is the classic sign of combination skin.

skin_tone_fitzpatrick.label: IV
skin_tone_fitzpatrick.note: Based on visual assessment of skin color and ethnicity context. This skin type tans easily and has a higher tendency for post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.

skin_age_range.rationale: The skin shows good firmness and elasticity with no significant static wrinkles. Very fine lines are beginning to appear in the periorbital area, which is consistent with the user's reported age of 27.

analysis.overview_explanation: Your skin appears to be the combination type, characterized by an oilier T-zone and more balanced cheeks. The primary areas for attention are the dark circles under your eyes, visibly enlarged pores on and around your nose, and some scattered spots of uneven pigmentation on your cheeks. Other concerns like wrinkles and redness are currently minimal.

pores.rationale_plain: You have moderately prominent pores, which are most noticeable in your T-zone. The pores on your nose and the parts of your cheeks closest to it appear larger and more concentrated. This pattern is common with combination and oily skin types.
possible_causes: Pore size is often determined by genetics.
Excess oil production can mix with dead skin cells, causing pores to become clogged and appear larger.
Sun exposure over time can also reduce skin elasticity, making pore walls slacken and look more prominent.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The enlarged pores are primarily located on your nose, forehead, and chin, which make up the T-zone.
likely_causes: This area of the face naturally has a higher concentration of oil glands.
Hormonal fluctuations can increase sebum production, making these pores more apparent.
care_education: Using products with ingredients like salicylic acid can help exfoliate inside the pores to keep them clear.
Ensuring your skin is well-hydrated can also help balance oil production over time.

wrinkles.rationale_plain: Your skin is largely smooth and firm, with no significant lines visible when your face is at rest. There are some very superficial, fine lines under the eyes, which is very common and can be related to expression, dehydration, or the natural thinness of the skin in that area.
possible_causes: Fine lines often first appear in areas with thin skin and frequent movement, like around the eyes.
Dehydration can temporarily make these lines look more pronounced.
Over time, collagen loss from sun exposure and natural aging contributes to the formation of static lines.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Very thin, shallow lines are visible on the skin surface, particularly in the under-eye area. They do not create shadows and are not deeply set.
likely_causes: These are often the first signs of changes in skin texture due to repetitive facial movements (like smiling or squinting).
Environmental factors and a lack of surface hydration can also contribute.
care_education: Keeping the delicate eye area well-moisturized with a dedicated eye cream can help plump the skin and soften the appearance of these lines.
Consistent sun protection is the most effective way to prevent premature aging and the deepening of lines.

pigmentation.rationale_plain: You have mild hyperpigmentation, visible as small, scattered darker spots (macules) primarily on your cheeks. The overall skin tone is slightly uneven. This pattern may be related to past inflammation (like breakouts) or cumulative sun exposure.
possible_causes: Dark spots can form after skin inflammation, a process known as post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH).
Sun exposure is a major contributor to uneven skin tone and the formation of sun spots, as UV rays stimulate melanin production.

identified_subtypes.explanation: There are discrete, small dark marks scattered on the cheeks that are likely the remnants of previous minor skin irritations or healed blemishes.
likely_causes: This occurs when the skin produces extra melanin in response to inflammation or injury.
Squeezing or picking at blemishes can increase the likelihood of PIH.
care_education: Sunscreen is crucial to prevent these spots from darkening further.
Ingredients like niacinamide, azelaic acid, and vitamin C can help to gradually fade the appearance of these marks over time.

citations.title: Skin Pigmentation Types, Causes and Treatmentâ€”A Review (PMC)

pigmentation.uncertainty_notes: The exact cause of pigmentation is difficult to determine from photos alone; it could be a mix of PIH and early sun damage.

redness.rationale_plain: Your overall skin tone shows minimal redness. There is a very faint, localized pinkish hue around the sides of your nose, which is a common area for slight irritation or sensitivity due to the facial structure.
possible_causes: The skin around the nostrils can be prone to mild irritation from environmental factors or rubbing.
For some people, it's just a natural variation in skin tone where the skin is thinner.

identified_subtypes.explanation: A faint reddish tone is confined to small, specific areas, most notably around the nasal folds (alae).
likely_causes: This can be due to a higher concentration of tiny blood vessels close to the surface in that area.
It can also be influenced by allergies, rubbing the nose, or mild irritation from skincare products.
care_education: A gentle skincare routine is always beneficial.
If the area feels sensitive, avoiding harsh scrubs and ensuring the skin is moisturized can help maintain a healthy skin barrier.

texture.rationale_plain: Your skin has a mildly uneven texture, characterized by a slight graininess and visible pores, particularly in the T-zone. It is not perfectly smooth, but it does not show signs of significant roughness or flaking.
possible_causes: Uneven texture is often linked to a buildup of dead skin cells on the surface.
Enlarged pores and minor, non-inflamed clogged pores can also contribute to a less-than-smooth appearance.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The skin's surface microrelief is not completely uniform, with visible pores and subtle variations contributing to a slightly rough appearance upon close inspection.
likely_causes: This can result from a combination of factors including genetics, sun exposure, and the accumulation of dead cells.
Dehydration can also temporarily accentuate textural irregularities.
care_education: Gentle exfoliation, using either chemical exfoliants (like AHAs or BHAs) or physical methods, can help to smooth the skin's surface.
Maintaining good hydration by drinking water and using moisturizers helps support smooth, healthy skin.

acne.rationale_plain: Your skin appears clear of any significant acne lesions. No inflammatory papules, pustules, or deeper nodules are visible in the photos provided.
possible_causes: At this level, skin is considered clear.
Minor clogged pores can still occur due to factors like oil production, dead skin cells, and environmental debris.

under_eye.rationale_plain: There is a moderate and distinct darkening of the skin under both of your eyes. This appears to be a brownish discoloration that covers the entire lower lid area, contributing to a tired look.
possible_causes: Under-eye circles are complex and can be caused by genetics, which can lead to thinner skin or more pigment in the area.
Lifestyle factors like lack of sleep, allergies, and sun exposure can also contribute to or worsen their appearance.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The darkness has a distinct brown tone, suggesting it is caused by an excess of melanin (pigment) in the skin under the eyes. This is common in deeper skin tones.
likely_causes: This can be hereditary and is often exacerbated by sun exposure, which stimulates pigment production.
Sometimes, rubbing the eyes due to allergies or habit can also lead to darkening over time.
care_education: Strict sun protection around the eyes is key to preventing further darkening.
Using an eye cream with ingredients like Vitamin C or retinoids (with caution) may help brighten the area over the long term.

identified_subtypes.explanation: In addition to the pigment, there is a slight indentation or hollow along the tear trough area. This can create a shadow that adds to the perception of darkness.
likely_causes: The shape of the bone and fat pads around the eye is determined by genetics.
Natural volume loss with age can also make these hollows more prominent.
care_education: While topical products can help with pigment and skin quality, they cannot change bone structure.
Keeping the skin hydrated and plump with moisturizers can have a minor softening effect on shadows.

under_eye.uncertainty_notes: It is difficult to fully separate pigmentary causes from structural shadowing with 2D photos. An in-person assessment can better distinguish the primary contributor.

limitations: This is a non-diagnostic visual assessment and not a substitute for professional medical advice.
Lighting conditions can affect the perception of skin tone, redness, and pigmentation.
Skin analysis is based on a single point in time and may not reflect dynamic changes.
